physical_appearance: The image shows two parts of a sari. Both are rectangular in shape, with the first part at the top being bigger than the second one at the bottom. They are predominantly green in colour, with yellow borders at the top and bottom for the first part of the garment, and at the sides for the second part of the garment. There are floral patterns in these yellow borders. Checked patterns can be seen all over the green region of both garments. There are green tassels extending from the right hand side of the first garment, and also from the top and bottom sides of the second garment.
sgcool_label_text: The sari is a traditional pan-Indian drape, woven in various parts of the sub-continent. Kanchipuram in Tamil Nadu, an illustrious weaving centre, is renowned for the “Kanchivaram Silk Sari”, worn during special occasions as well as by Tamil brides. This collection of saris were donated by Dr.R.D.Gangatharan in memory of his mother, the late Lakshmi Rangasamy Davar. Lakshmi Rangasamy Davar, was a woman pioneer – she was an educationist, musician and philanthropist.
subject_terms_1: womenswear folk costume floral patterns allover patterns checker pattern
